description: From Latin expiātus, past participle of expiō (“atone for”).

verbs.description: expiate (third-person singular simple present expiates, present participle expiating, simple past and past participle expiated)

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive) To atone or make reparation for.
examples: Thus those pious souls who expiate the remainder of their sins amidst such tortures will receive a special and opportune consolation,  […]

entries.meaning: (transitive) To make amends or pay the penalty for.
examples: He had only to live and expiate in solitude the crimes which he had committed.

entries.meaning: (transitive, obsolete) To relieve or cleanse of guilt.
examples: […]  and Epimenides was brought from Crete to expiate the city.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To wind up, bring to an end.
